results.abstract: Col Susan B Helms and Col James S Voss, new American astronauts aboard international space station, say they will welcome Dennis Tito, California millionaire, if he is brought aboard station by Russian cosmonauts over objections of NASA (M)

headline.main: Astronauts Say Millionaire Tourist Is Welcome

results.snippet: The newest residents of the international space station say they will welcome a California millionaire if he shows up at their door next month over NASA's objections.    The American astronaut Col. Susan B. Helms said Friday that she and her crew...
results.lead_paragraph: The newest residents of the international space station say they will welcome a California millionaire if he shows up at their door next month over NASA's objections. The American astronaut Col. Susan B. Helms said Friday that she and her crew mate Col. James S. Voss barely knew Dennis Tito, who is trying to become the world's first space tourist. But Colonel Helms pointed out that she and Colonel Voss did not know the two Russian cosmonauts who are expected to accompany Mr. Tito in the Soyuz spacecraft.

results.abstract: Scott Carpenter letter on Henry S F Cooper Jr March 11 review of Flight: My Life in Mission Control by Chris Kraft (S)

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: FLIGHT: MY LIFE IN MISSION CONTROL (BOOK)

results.snippet: To the Editor:    Regarding Henry S. F. Cooper Jr.'s review of ''Flight: My Life in Mission Control'' (March 11), Chris Kraft's new memoir:    John Glenn's historic flight aboard Friendship 7 took place more than 39 years ago. I was his backup...
results.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Regarding Henry S. F. Cooper Jr.'s review of ''Flight: My Life in Mission Control'' (March 11), Chris Kraft's new memoir: John Glenn's historic flight aboard Friendship 7 took place more than 39 years ago. I was his backup pilot. Rightly or wrongly, Deke Slayton was ruled ineligible for the follow-up flight because of a minor heart condition. Rightly or wrongly, I was named to take his place. All manners of hard feelings stemmed from these two unpopular decisions, which I did not make and over which I had no control. I took the flight, named my capsule Aurora 7 and trained hard for the six weeks I had. The flight plan, originally Deke's, called for a number of radical space maneuvers, more photography, more observation and some experiments, all of which I accomplished, in addition to returning safely to earth with the capsule unharmed. These facts alone should be enough to vindicate the flight of Aurora 7. But there was even more: the system failures I encountered during the flight would have resulted in loss of the capsule and total mission failure had a man not been aboard. My postflight debriefings and reports led, in turn, to important changes in capsule design and future flight plans. These too I consider major contributions to our knowledge about spaceflight and to the successes that Wally Schirra and Gordo Cooper met with in their own subsequent flights. Chris Kraft and I have always been at odds about my flight. Yet in his review of ''Flight,'' Henry Cooper seems unaware of the dispute. Chris's style, he says admiringly, succeeds in ''pulling no punches,'' as though this promises a candid and true book, when it could instead be merely vindictive and skewed. A question lingers in this rattled old septuagenarian brain: why is Chris still in the ring throwing punches? Finally, the reviewer notes with interest Chris's early, stark realization that ''things happened so fast in rocketry that an astronaut couldn't do anything'' without help from the ground. A debatable proposition. In any event, Chris never acknowledged that the reverse also holds true: in space things happen so fast that only the pilot knows what to do, and even ground control can't help. Maybe that's why he is still fuming after all these years. Scott Carpenter Vail, Colo.

results.snippet: ISN'T that just like a director? He casts his own mother in a tiny part, then makes her a scene stealer. In APOLLO 13 (1995), when the astronaut James Lovell's wife and colleagues are terrified that Lovell is going to die in space and they very...
results.lead_paragraph: ISN'T that just like a director? He casts his own mother in a tiny part, then makes her a scene stealer. In APOLLO 13 (1995), when the astronaut James Lovell's wife and colleagues are terrified that Lovell is going to die in space and they very gingerly explain to his elderly mother (Jean Speegle Howard, mother of Ron) that her son is in a tiny bit of danger, she doesn't blink an eye. ''If they could get a washing machine to fly,'' she reassures her little granddaughter, ''my Jimmy could land it.'' And it turns out she's right. Tom Hanks, Bill Paxton and Kevin Bacon play the astronauts whose moon landing shot is canceled because of an oxygen tank explosion that creates a life-threatening, nation-uniting crisis. The people on the ground are memorable, too: Kathleen Quinlan as Lovell's wife, Ed Harris as the flight commander, Gary Sinise as the astronaut bumped from the flight because he'd been exposed to measles. And what an elating tribute to old-fashioned American know-how! -- Saturday at 8 p.m. on Channel 7.

results.snippet: DRS TECHNOLOGIES INC., Parsippany, N.J., a maker of surveillance and radar systems for the military, said it had won a $29 million order to upgrade recording equipment in the Navy's antisubmarine patrol aircraft.
results.lead_paragraph: DRS TECHNOLOGIES INC., Parsippany, N.J., a maker of surveillance and radar systems for the military, said it had won a $29 million order to upgrade recording equipment in the Navy's antisubmarine patrol aircraft.

results.snippet: Who can remember life before multitasking? These days we all do it: mothers, air-traffic controllers, ambidextrous athletes, high-flying executives who manage to eat, take conference calls, write e-mail and conduct board meetings all at the same...
results.lead_paragraph: Who can remember life before multitasking? These days we all do it: mothers, air-traffic controllers, ambidextrous athletes, high-flying executives who manage to eat, take conference calls, write e-mail and conduct board meetings all at the same time. We lionize those who appear to multitask effortlessly and despair at our own haphazard attempts to juggle even two tasks, secretly wondering if there exists a race of superior beings whose brains are hard-wired for multitasking feats. Only recently have neurologists begun to understand what our brains are up to when we do it. What they've learned offers hope to all multitasking delinquents out there. 1. Don't think you can actually do two things at once. Even when you think you're doing more than one thing simultaneously -- say, driving and talking on a cell phone -- you aren't. Unlike a computer, the brain isn't structured as a parallel processor. It performs actions, even very simple actions, in a strict linear sequence. You must complete the first task, or part of that task, before moving on to the next. What we call multitasking is actually task switching.

results.abstract: Space shuttle Endeavour is set for launching on mission to deliver mobile robotic arm to International Space Station, Canada's main contribution to project; arm is designed to mvoe itself all abut station, serving as hands and eyes of crew wherever outside work is needed; drawing (L)

headline.main: Special Delivery for the Space Station: A Robotic Arm

results.snippet: The International Space Station is to receive a major arm up this week when astronauts aboard the shuttle Endeavour deliver a robot helper critical to expanding and maintaining the orbiting laboratory.    Endeavour, carrying a diverse international...
results.lead_paragraph: The International Space Station is to receive a major arm up this week when astronauts aboard the shuttle Endeavour deliver a robot helper critical to expanding and maintaining the orbiting laboratory. Endeavour, carrying a diverse international crew of seven, is to blast off from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida on Thursday with Canada's main contribution to the project, a mobile robotic arm.

headline.main: Shuttle Endeavour Heads to Space Station

results.snippet: The space shuttle Endeavour blasted off today from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida carrying a giant mechanical arm that will be used to expand the growing International Space Station.    Endeavour and its crew of seven astronauts took off on time...
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Endeavour blasted off today from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida carrying a giant mechanical arm that will be used to expand the growing International Space Station. Endeavour and its crew of seven astronauts took off on time into cloud-streaked blue skies at 2:40 p.m. as the station and its resident crew of three passed the Indian Ocean. The shuttle is to chase the station around the Earth before docking with it on Saturday.

results.abstract: Space shuttle Endeavour docks with International Space Station to deliver billion-dollar robot arm that will act as high-tech construction crane; Endeavour's seven astronauts are first visitors for Russian commander Yuri V Usachev and American astronauts Susan B Helms and James S Voss since they arrived in Mar for 4.5-month stay; two crews will not meet face to face until Apr 23 because Endeavour must maintain lower cabin pressure in anticipation of spacewalk (M)

headline.main: Shuttle Docks With Station, Crane in Tow

results.snippet: The space shuttle Endeavour docked with the International Space Station today to deliver a billion-dollar robot arm that will act as a high-tech construction crane.    The mission commander, Capt. Kent V. Rominger of the Navy, manually steered the...
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Endeavour docked with the International Space Station today to deliver a billion-dollar robot arm that will act as a high-tech construction crane. The mission commander, Capt. Kent V. Rominger of the Navy, manually steered the shuttle through its final paces to hook up with the station over the South Pacific.

results.abstract: Comment on tributes to World War II generation in film and print; photos; Michael Bay, director of new movie Pearl Harbor, comments (M)

headline.main: Raising a Flag for Generation W.W. II

results.snippet: IT had been a long, hot weekend securing the beaches of Punta Cana, on the tourist stronghold of the Dominican Republic. The coral had taken its toll on the snorkel team. Some of us got pinned down by the pool without sunscreen. Mosquitoes the size...
results.lead_paragraph: IT had been a long, hot weekend securing the beaches of Punta Cana, on the tourist stronghold of the Dominican Republic. The coral had taken its toll on the snorkel team. Some of us got pinned down by the pool without sunscreen. Mosquitoes the size of Messerschmitts dive-bombed the tennis courts. Somehow our four-man, four-woman squad made it out alive. Peace is hell.

results.abstract: David M Walker, retired astronaut who flew on four space shuttle missions and was decorated as Navy fighter pilot, dies at age 56; photo (M)

headline.main: David M. Walker, 56, Astronaut and Aviator

results.snippet: David M. Walker, a retired astronaut who flew on four space shuttle missions and was decorated as a Navy fighter pilot, died yesterday at a cancer center in Houston. He was 56 and lived near Boise, Idaho.    Mr. Walker's family said his illness was...
results.lead_paragraph: David M. Walker, a retired astronaut who flew on four space shuttle missions and was decorated as a Navy fighter pilot, died yesterday at a cancer center in Houston. He was 56 and lived near Boise, Idaho. Mr. Walker's family said his illness was sudden and recent, but they did not give any details.

results.abstract: Eighteen nations building International Space Station agree to Russia's demand that American Dennis Tito be allowed to visit station as first space tourist, but only if his activities and those of resident crew are restricted; Tito has agreed to pay Russian Aviation and Space Agency up to $20 million for trip; Lt Gen Thomas P Stafford says Tito will be limited to Russian modules because he lacks training on American modules; photo (M)

headline.main: Russia Wins Fight to Be First Space Travel Agent

results.snippet: The partners building the International Space Station agreed today to allow an American millionaire to visit the station as the first space tourist, but only if his activities and those of the resident crew were restricted.    The 18 nations building...
results.lead_paragraph: The partners building the International Space Station agreed today to allow an American millionaire to visit the station as the first space tourist, but only if his activities and those of the resident crew were restricted. The 18 nations building the station, represented by the space agencies of the United States, Russia, Europe, Canada and Japan, signed an agreement exempting the American, Dennis Tito, from current guidelines that do not allow for nonastronauts to visit the station.
